item.content:
Envy

Envy is a linter for .env files written in Go. It aims to be fast, accurate, and easy to use. It runs on Windows, Linux, and macOS.

Envy can help lint single .env files, lint entire directories of .env files, or be integrated into CI to lint build and deployment stage .env files.

Envy was inspired by the Rust .env linter dotenv-linter, with the aim to provide similar functionality, but from a tool written in Go.

Envy checks .env files for things like:

  • duplicate keys
  • unordered keys
  • malformed keys
  • malformed values
  • incorrect casing
  • incorrect spacing
  • incorrect quoting

Read more about usage and checks, or check out the source

item.content:
Envy checks for the following .env file best practices and required items.

Checks

  • Valid key
  • Valid value
  • Valid key prefix
  • No empty value

Uh oh, this is a note this is a thing

c1. Valid Key

Checks that the key is valid. A valid key should consiste of only capital letters, numbers, and underscores.

  • ✅ MY_KEY=value
  • ❌ my-key=value

c2. Valid value

Checks that they value is valid. A valid value must be a non-empty string.

  • ✅ MY_KEY=value
  • ❌ MY_KEY=

c3. Valid key prefix

Checks that the first character of the key is valid. A valid key prefix must be a capital letter or a number.

  • ✅ MY_KEY=value
  • ❌ mY_KEY=value

c4. No empty value

Checks that the value is not an empty string.

  • ✅ MY_KEY=value
  • ❌ MY_KEY=

item.content:
How to install and use envy.

Setup

Install envy.

go get github.com/envy-lint/envy

Usage

You can run envy several ways.

Default

By default, envy will look for a .env file in the current directory.

envy

Specify file

Specify a file with the -f flag.

envy -f sample.env

Stdin

Pipe output to envy.

echo sample.env | envy
